qas.question: The americo-liberians did not identify with who?
What were americo-liberians encounters like with tribal Africans"

answers.text: the Kru and Grebo people from their inland chiefdoms.

qas.question: What did Americo-liberians exclude tribes from?
Americo-Liberians set up missions and schools to do what?
Who did the Americo-Liberian settlers raid?
What groups killed the Americo-Liberian children?

plausible_answers.text: a western-style state to which the tribesmen should assimilate

qas.question: What did the indigenous peoples envision creating?
The indigenous tribesmen set up missions and schools to do what?
In what year were indigenous tribesmen allowed to become Liberian citizens?

context: The Americo-Liberian settlers did not identify with the <a0_0><b5_0>indigenous peoples they encountered<b5_0/>,<a0_0/> especially those in communities of the more isolated "bush." They knew nothing of their cultures, languages or animist religion. Encounters with tribal Africans in the bush often developed as <a1_0>violent confrontations.<a1_0/> The colonial settlements were raided by <a2_0>the <b6_0>Kru and Grebo people<b6_0/> from their inland chiefdoms.<a2_0/> Because of feeling set apart and superior by their culture and education to the indigenous peoples, the Americo-Liberians developed as a small elite that held on to political power. It excluded the indigenous tribesmen from birthright <a3_0>citizenship in their own lands<a3_0/> until <b9_0>1904<b9_0/>, in a repetition of the United States' treatment of Native Americans. Because of the cultural gap between the groups and assumption of superiority of western culture, the Americo-Liberians envisioned creating <b7_0>a western-style state to which the tribesmen should assimilate<b7_0/>. They encouraged religious organizations to set up missions and schools <a4_0>to <b8_0>educate the indigenous peoples<b8_0/>.
